Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Anything harsh or derogatory regarding someone's identity, such as their looks, race, gender, or sexual orientation, is considered an identity attack.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: Of course, free trade was actually a long standing policy of the Liberal Party and anti-free trade the policy of the Conservative/Progressive Conservative Party. That includes the Fall of the Laurier led Liberal government in 1911 to the Conservatives who ran on an virulent anti-reciprocity (free trade) platform. The Liberals continued the free trade orientation though regular tariff reductions through GATT and other mechanisms with the US, often facing partisan opposition from the PCs. 

The FTA was a key recommendation of the Macdonald Commission formed under Trudeau in 1981 , reporting after the change in government.  Brian Mulrony and the Conservatives actually ran on an anti-free trade platform in 1984. 

Then they flip-flopped. So the Liberals decided to flop the other way in 1988. Overall, lots of partisanship and flip-flops.

Comment: Originally, for the first 125 years of this country, the only people we elected by popular vote to represent us in the federal government were members of the House of Representatives.  Senators were elected "indirectly" by state legislatures, until the 17th Amendment was ratified, which made them elected by popular vote.  We have never elected our Presidents by popular vote.

James Madison, writing as Publius in the Federalist Papers, wrote extensively about the "#1 Disease" endemic in a republican form of government, which is the tendency for a self-interested majority to trample on the rights of individuals and minorities,  and that history had shown that periodic elections weren't sufficient to guard against this "tyranny of the majority;" extraordinary measures need to be taken to protect against it.  This led to three co-equal branches of government:  Legislative, Executive, and Judicial, only one of which is elected "democratically."  It also led to the division of Congress into

Comment: Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's home is just outside Charlottesville VA and as a World Heritage Site presumably will not be torn down just because Tom held over 100  slaves there.

It's a worthwhile visit and for those who will miss General Lee's statue, General Stonewall Jackson's stuffed horse is in a glass display case at the Virginia Military Institute (VMI) Museum in Lexington VA beside the raincoat Jackson was wearing when he was shot by "friendly fire". 

We were given a tour by a very polite cadet...but that was many years ago.  He was so proud to point out the bullet hole to the children and talk about the young VMI cadets being sent into the  Battle of New Market in May of 1864.

I know the Civil War went on for almost another year, but sending young cadets into battle as I recall sounded a bit like the fall of Berlin...but we didn't say anything as were just visiting and that wouldn't have been polite...and manners are so important in the south!

Comment: Actually, the history of our very own state suggests otherwise. Alaska had an income tax until 1980. We were able to eliminate it because (at the time) we had enough oil tax revenue to fund the state. And I don't feel at all guilty ... I'm just providing a business owner's perspective, which is actually pretty simple:

Business like mine require a talented and highly trained workforce, and this in turn requires substantial investment in public education at both the K-12 and the University level. Further, my employees all want to live in safe, healthy communities with quality roads, parks, clean water, public art, etc. These things all requires public investment.

If Alaskans are unwilling to make this kind of investment, then these people will simply leave for other states with a different attitude. And since they have a skillset that is in high demand all over the country that's easy for them to do. That in turn will force high-tech business in Alaska to close their doors.

Comment: Unfortunately, the author really doesn't suggest any solutions which I anticipated since near the beginning he said he was issuing a challenge to the system.  It was an informative article but really doesn't add anything new to the discussion.  The fact is that benefits for PERS Tier 1 beneficiaries are going to handicap this state in the provision of services for the next thirty to forty years.  PERS will continue to dominate all of our public discussions about state finances.  The Supreme Court of Oregon has upheld the contractual rights of beneficiaries to receive the benefits they were promised regardless of the implications.  All public monies must first be applied towards the obligation to these beneficiaries.   When a public body establishes a budget the costs for PERS contributions come right off the top.  Then the agency figures out how to make do with what is left.  Usually that means cuts in services.  The hands of our leaders are largely tied when it comes to this issue.

Comment: I spent 2-3 days in Bethel in 2014. I was appalled at the prices in the AC. I literally remember seeing 24 packs of Kirkland bottled water for $30+. A half gallon of MinuteMaid Orange juice was $10.60. 

What I remembered thinking at the time was what a colossal arbitrage opportunity this was. Just on shelf-stable goods alone, the markup seemed to be somewhere between 100-600%. I thought if I just owned a barge, I would bring goods to Bethel and undercut the obscene prices. 

I realize the cost of ownership and maintenance of such transport vessels is high. I could never afford it. But the City of Bethel? I see barges on the marketplace for <5 Million. Put the transport and maintenance at $10 million total. How long would it take you running shelf stable goods at 500% markup before you'd pay that off, even on high side cost estimates? I wish there was more proactive and altruistic efforts like this in Alaska. Just my silly two cents.

Comment: Thetus Smith - you presume to speak for the people of Alaska. Have you bothered to speak to us? You certainly haven't bothered to speak to me or any of the many people who agree with me.

1. We believe that a state income tax will gut Alaska economy and drive some working families toward bankruptcy.
2. We agree with you on the wasteful spending, but probably not on the particulars of what constitutes waste.
3. I would rather lose the PFD than pay an income tax because a reduction in the PFD is an equal tax on every citizen of the state rather than an unequal tax on those of us who work.

5. We believe the economic health of the state is damaged by social programs, so the State should only provide them when absolutely necessary.

Don't assume that yours is the majority opinion. Our legislators are hearing from us who are sensible as well as you who are economically clueless.

Comment: Oh yes, there are very significant differences between the Arar and Khadr cases. Chief among them, Maher Arar endured 'just' a year of abuse in a foreign prison. Omar Khadr spent almost 10 years in a foreign prison, during which time the Canadian government participated in his abuse and prolonged his incarceration.

The misinformation on Mr. Arar that the Canadian government passed to the Americans was in error, but it was an honest one. No malice was intended. Surely we can agree that the government didn't expect him to be tortured in a Syrian prison over it. However in the Khadr case, agents of the Canadian government actively violated his rights, and knowingly benefited from the abuses he suffered.

If you believe that the Charter should apply equally to all citizens, no matter how distasteful the circumstances, then Khadr's alleged crimes are of no relevance. Yet the transgressions of the Canadian government in the Khadr case are far worse.

Comment: We are obliged to keep forgiving. The individual seeking forgiveness must ask for it, be it from God or fellow human.

Judaism teaches those who have done wrong  seek forgiveness. The offender must sincerely ask pardon and seek to correct the wrongs he has done. After a certain point-- three sincere apologies, an attempt at restitution, a clear indication that the person has changed - it becomes the obligation of the wronged party to forgive. 

The rabbis agree that teshuvah (repentance) requires five elements: recognition of one's sins as sins (hakarát ha-chét'), remorse (charatá), desisting from sin (azivát ha-chét'), restitution where possible (peira'ón), and confession (vidúi). The tradition is also quite clear, however, that  if they are done without desisting from sin, they do not constitute teshuva.

What Jesus changed was the number of time we should forgive. The rest reads like a manual for the sacrament of Penance.

Comment: I read the posting from Medical Doctor and it confirmed that Americans survive cancer at rates in excess of Brits.  It suggested, without data or evidence, this may be due to misdiagnosis or over-diagnosis.    I found a Daily Mail story about the difference in survival rates between American woman with Breast Cancer and women in the UK with Breast Cancer.  They report that the five year Breast Cancer survival rate was 78% in the UK and 97% in America.  They note that American diagnosis and treatment are more aggressive.  Routine breast screening starts at age 40 in America and 50 in the UK.  They also reported that Herceptin, which  proved to be effective, in clincial trials, took two years for approval in the UK, even though it was available in the US.  Cost appeared to be a factor.

Comment: The manner in which Canada and other countries simply handed out money in the past did not work well - most of it did not get to those in need. Consequently we developed programs to encourage sustainable industries in the poorest countries in the world by providing zero duty rates on goods manufactured in those countries. While perhaps it does not create quite the same excitement as the old method of handing out money to corrupt governments in the hope that some of it would trickle down to those that we were trying to help, it does seem to work better. Bangladesh and the other LDCs now have thriving manufacturing sectors and people are working and finally there is some progress. 
Mr Greenhill does not include the cost of the many billions of dollars in import duty subsidies which Canada provides to all the LDCs in his calculations and instead is simply comparing direct cash subsidies. In doing so he paints an incomplete picture.

Comment: "...selling our uranium?"  Well, it was a Canadian owned company that had the rights to the uranium when it sold it's controlling interest to Rosatom, so it's not clear that it was "ours" then.  Furthermore,  no Uranium One, Inc.-produced uranium has been shipped directly to Russia and the U.S. Government has not authorized any country to re-transfer U.S. uranium to Russia. And there's more; the Committee on Foreign Investments (CFI) that reviewed the sale has nine members, including the secretaries of the treasury, state, defense, homeland security, commerce and energy; the attorney general; and representatives from two White House offices.  Furthermore, the CFI only has review capability, it cannot prohibit a sale.  So this is really a non-story cooked up by a Peter Schweizer to promote his book sales to easily duped conspiracy-hungry buyers.He has long history of dubious reporting.  Do some homework.

Comment: Ticket sales never cover more than about one-third of opera company costs, here or anywhere else. The rest of the revenue comes in the form of donations plus a few grants now and then. And donors never represent more than a small fraction of the community. Most of the people who attend operas in Eugene donate very little, if anything, beyond the price of their tickets. The fact is, a small number of donors who really love opera are carrying the ball for the rest of the community. The real question is whether they will continue to support opera here. Opera is one of the performing arts that attracts educated people to relocate to Eugene, and that makes it easier to attract employers and grow the economy. Whether you like opera or not, Eugene will be the poorer if Eugene Opera fails to recover.

Comment: I agree with you that scapegoating snorkels masks the true complexity of the problem (pun unintended). Ocean safety as well as trail safety requires a more comprehensive solution than blaming the equipment or individual people. I'm seeing a lot of calls for more education, but in my experience, knowledge alone rarely leads to better decision-making. Furthermore, over-regulation will simply drive business away or cause tour operators to implement token solutions (such as a safety video nobody watches). What I would advocate is education + effective regulation (informed by data and input from businesses and safety experts) + cultural change. One of the major promoters of safety can be the Hawaii residents who aren't drowning at such high rates. Tourists rarely go out without asking hotel staff, or checking online sources such as yelp/blog. When we see tourists doing stupid dangerous things, say something... and say it with Aloha. Re-enforce the message.

Comment: I don't actually agree with your assessment. But let's leave that aside as we'll likely never agree.

Right now though - the more important message is the one that's in the article: this is a reason to trust the DA more. Alone among all South African political parties, this one has shown itself willing and able to severely chastise a senior leader (with strong struggle credentials no less) for screwing up. How much better off would we not be if ANC leaders who did fundamentally stupid things got this level of punishment every single time ?

This is something we should all be in favor off. Even if you feel her offense was not so bad - you should be glad that the DA is setting an example of actually punishing people who broke the rules (even if you don't agree with the specific rules).  Even if their past behavior was heroic. 
We need to spread that attitude throughout our politics, not complain about the one party that actually has it.

Comment: Sounds like the police may have been violating FAA rules : Sec. 91.119 — Minimum safe altitudes: General.
Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, no person may operate an aircraft below the following altitudes:

(a) Anywhere. An altitude allowing, if a power unit fails, an emergency landing without undue hazard to persons or property on the surface.

(b) Over congested areas. Over any congested area of a city, town, or settlement, or over any open air assembly of persons, an altitude of 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 2,000 feet of the aircraft.

Comment: Not really... the Cement Creek basin is one seriously sulfidic, and therefore acidic, beast.  Where we get the largest of that actions is once CC hits the Animas River.  If one were incredibly bold, they could divert the animas above the CC and animas confluence and use lower CC as a neutralizing and then settling basin, but that's not in the cards for a whole host of reasons that I'm sure you could imagine.

At this point the best high (relatively) pH water entering the basin is from the Red and Bonita!  You could say they hit the lucky-loo jackpot when they bulkheaded the American and the water emerged from the R&B with a higher pH!  (And counter-argue the deteriorated water from GK means zero net benefit.) Regardless, the R&B shouldn't be held back from the stream. It should be put through a massive DAS (Dispersed alkaline substrate, usually limestone) wetland and allowed to flow into the stream system at a pH ~8 and loaded with pH buffering carbonates.

Comment: While this opinion piece is written by parties who have a vested interest and must be carefully scrutinized, they make some good points.  Lower paid non-tenured faculty are an important part of an efficiently run modern University.  It is important to have a portion of the faculty that takes teaching as a first priority rather than research.  The teaching portion of the faculty is cost effective in supporting the primary educational function of the University.  Research is a secondary function of the University and it is very expensive.  Tenure-track faculty are typically heavily involved in research which requires substantial time.  Such faculty may teach only one course per term (or none).  The trustees, as representatives? of the citizens of Oregon, must decide whether to go with cost effective contract employees or expensive tenure-track faculty.  Truth be told, research provides limited benefit to Oregonians but is very expensive.  (A former tenured professor.)

Comment: Good idea to change session to 90 days in the constitution.
From day one, they create operational and capital budgets.
Nothing else is done until this is accomplished.
Then they can do all that other self serving legislation that gets them praise and re-elected.
At the end of 90 days, no more money.
Go home and face their constituents.
Go back to their real job.
The one where they will get fired if they do not produce a meaningful and measurable product.

Two budgets (and other things as time permits). 
Meaningful and measurable performance.
Go home (or wherever) on day 91.
No more money.

$50,000 for 90 days, amortizes to a minimum of $202,777.78 per year effective salary (not including the hundreds per day of expenses on top of that, amortizes to another tidy sum).
That is a fairly hefty compensation for that period of time, and we should expect that sort of value in accomplished performance as a result.

Given our future financial situation, Legislature cost containment makes sense.

Comment: I think you underestimate immigrant thinking. I'm an immigrant myself, albeit from quite a while ago and I would not like to see a flood of immigrants from the same background as myself coming here and either deliberately or not, changing the nature of Canada.  It's not a simple "pull up the drawbridge" reaction. I came here because Iliked the idea of Canada, not because I was running away from anything. I wanted to contribute to Canadian values and progress. I oppose immigration which would tilt our society away from its steadily progressive, economically-viable position. In my opinion, the best way to solve this issue is to discontinue all the various kinds of visas in favour of only one - a 5-year non-renewable immigrant visa. During the five years the immigrant would have to apply for full citizenship, the test for which should include a very tough test of fluency in at least one of our official languages which would make integration almost inevitable.

At this, the angels in heaven began to shout with joy. And the Holy One, blessed be he, rebuked them, saying, "Why are you rejoicing over the misfortunes of the Egyptians? Scripture tells us. "Have we not all the one Father? Has not the one God created all of us? Why then do we break faith with our brothers and sisters, violating the covenant of our ancestors?" (Malachi 2:10)

Comment: "There is lots of research out there that shows women are just as interested in being entrepreneurs as men"

Which is irrelevant. The percentage that are "interested" and the percentage that actually go and start a corporation are miles apart, so there's virtually nothing to be gleaned from studies about interest. Who starts real world businesses, not wannabe businesses that only exist as concepts in their heads?

There's reams of evidence showing sizeable sex differences in how risk gets analyzed, how risk is perceived, and a pretty vast gulf in risk tolerance between men and women.  Nearly equal rates of interest are almost virtually guaranteed to produce fewer women that pull that trigger and actually start those businesses, given what we measure about how they perceive risk. Just look at where women collect in entrepreneurship - small, service oriented businesses that have little to no risk. They probably face *some* discrimination, but the vast bulk of their issue is engagement.

Comment: Disney should have asked for a correction (or multiple ones).  That being said, journalistic integrity has fallen to an abysmal low in recent years, and we are all worse off for it.  There are necessarily two components to journalism-- WHAT happened, and WHAT ABOUT IT. The former is facts, and ONLY facts.  The latter is OPINION, and just that.  Far too much of what passes off as news these days dangerously combines both facts and opinion.  You must know just the facts before you can have an opinion.  We all need just the facts first.  Otherwise we don't have the full picture.  Still, good on Disney for lifting the ban, and I think in the future, they'll be better at combating what might otherwise be inaccurate journalism, they have smart people there.

Comment: The tax treaty simply means that there is no withholding tax in retirement accounts (i.e. RRSP and LIRA).  That in itself doesn't make US content preferential for an RRSP account.  Canadian stocks that don't pay eligible dividends or dividends at all would be subject to the same rates of tax in a cash account as US stocks.

So depending on your tax rate now and projected tax rate in retirement and overall portfolio structure there may be a valid argument that your eligible Canadian dividends should be invested outside of your RRSP which may leave more room for US or other foreign content.

That said of course one also needs to consider capital gains taxation since an RRSP also results in capital gains being treated as regular income.

As you say one needs to figure out an optimum solution that works for them.  For most people that is likely going to result in their RRSP holding a mixture of Canadian and US content and a mixture of dividend stocks and non dividend stocks.

Comment: I believe that this is a poor idea. Canada needs investment dollars and an increase in capital gains taxes will not encourage this investment. In addition, studies have shown in the past that there is a point where high cap gains rates will encourage people to hold on to their gains, not liquidate a thereby not generate  as much tax revenue. There is probably evidence of the effect of the inclusion rates based on what happened to government cap gain revenue when the rate was lowered by Paul Martin from 75% tp 50%. My guess is that not much tax revenue was lost as there were more trades generating less revenue per trade. I would bet that if the government was looking for more tax revenue that the best option would be to lower the inclusion rate to something like 25% which would encourage Canadians to move from one investment to another with lower tax ramifications. Again, fewer taxes per trade but more trades. Very significant for aging Canadians.

Comment: Our current FPTP system has some short comings.  The problem is that there is no silver bullet.  There is no system that stands out as clearly superior.  All systems have their short comings.  If you were to change the voting system you would be exchanging the short comings of the current system with those of another.  You could grade all the proposed systems based on a set of criteria.  The results of grading would show there was no clear winner.  The results would also show that our current system would rank comparably high.  This is because FPTP ranks high in accountability, simplicity and stability.  Of course, there are always those that don’t want to evaluate a system on a full set of criteria.  They have their pet system that satisfies their narrow self-interest.

Comment: This is example is actually very different to urban planning: the Kings was urban re-generation from industrialisation, not in need of urban planning (there were already roads and infrastructure and proximity to the business district and Union Station). 

Toronto - and Canada in fact - needs proper urban planning and planning for population increases. Getting the 'bones' right of urban planning is key. For example, creating new cities on a hub and spoke design for roads and public transport. Hardwiring in cycle and walking paths and parks/green spaces. Using smart tech from the start. 

Get the bones right and the development will flourish. There is nothing more attractive to investors and developers and new businesses than to know there is already excellent public transport for workers and that they will enjoy moving to the area with their families; that the tech infrastructure is 21st century.

Comment: It's a good thing that Alaska's urban-dwelling moose are tolerated and even shown a great deal of respect. But some cow moose protecting their calves seem to believe that the best defense is a good offense. I've seen these cows lurking in the woods along bike trails and in wooded lots in subdivisions. Sometimes they can't be seen until you are dozens of feet away. Some cow moose charge when they see a person a block or more away. When a cow like that takes up residence in a neighborhood, it can be dangerous stepping out of your car. And what about kids, who are now out of school? Is every kid in the neighborhood supposed to play indoors for a month or more?

When I was the local state biologist I had to kill several cows who, if I walked away, were almost certainly going to kill or maim someone. The decision is not lightly made, but sometimes it is necessary. People also inhabit Anchorage.

Comment: Despite China beating India in the 1962 war, there are two incidents, which the Chinese government, media, and academia fail (read: make illegal) to report - the defeat of the Chinese by India in 1967. 

The Nathu La and Cho La clashes (11–14 September 1967 for Nathu La; 1 October 1967 for Cho La) were a series of military clashes between India and China alongside the border of the Himalayan Kingdom of Sikkim, then an Indian protectorate.
The Nathu La clashes started on 11 September 1967, when the People's Liberation Army (PLA) launched an attack on Indian posts at Nathu La, and lasted till 15 September 1967. In October 1967, another military duel took place at Cho La and ended on the same day.
According to some independent sources, the Indian forces achieved "decisive tactical advantage" and defeated the Chinese forces in these clashes. Many PLA fortifications at Nathu La were said to be destroyed, where the Indian troops drove back the attacking Chinese forces.

Comment: Is that to mean that big and fast players shouldn't be allowed to play?  The comment is anecdotal and irrelevant to a meaningful solution.  In the 60's hockey players didn't wear helmets.  I don't think we want to return to that reality.  
As a youth hockey trainer today my biggest worry isn't contact to the head from an opponent, but head contact with the boards and ice.  I see this far more often with the speed kids are playing at today and it is equally as consequential when it occurs.  By in large head contact is illegal for all minor hockey players regardless of what the NHL is doing, so I believe we are already on the right track.  
If the NHL wants to continue to ignore the problem then I sincerely hope those expansion fees are being well invested because they'll need all the money they can find to settle lawsuits.

Comment: While I agree with you for the most part, based on the research I did, the satellite network that device uses is not as reliable as the 406MHz frequency the basic PLBs use.  In order for the inReach to function, the satellite it's talking to had to simultaneously have a clear view of the transmitting unit and the ground station it's relaying to, otherwise there can be significant delays. The 406mhz ones only need to see the unit transmitting the signal for the alert to be passed on.  For that reason I carry a basic PLB.  Thanks for your reply!

Comment: Apples and oranges, Lynn. Other funding formulas are not derived from the Constitution as the PFD is. The Supreme Court has previously stated that this transfer is automatic and is not an appropriation - which means it can't be vetoed.

Comment: To reinforce with some actual figures:
When I worked for a large multinational (name withheld to protect the guilty!), all our imported products were marked up by 66% of landed cost (the latter including manufacturing and shipping costs and a slice of parent-company profit).  We ran a single-level direct-to-user selling operation (no wholesale / retail structure), and by the time the company bookkeepers had finished with us, we were lucky to show a departmental bottom-line nett profit above 3% on our sales: such was the nature of corporate overhead costing.
...so much for the indignant contrasting of input / output price levels, to provide a loaded "shaming" of the retailers.

Comment: Bavius - in the UK referendum results are not binding on the Government.  So the government can actually ignore them if they wish. However I am sure they would be slaughtered in the next election.

The Judges could not comment in their position as members of the Supreme Court prior to the referendum as no case or question was referred to them by parliament. They cannot just go throwing out opinions with first being asked.  In this case someone filed a case against the government, the court sided with them.

I am not sure what May is so concerned about - if she is sure in her position the court will side with the government in January.  If they don't she has to call a vote in Parliament - which she could have called any time since the referendum.  The Judges are not preventing the government from invoking article 50, they at most will delay it a little for parliament to have their say  - which is what they are paid for in the first place.

Comment: The cabbie's clothing and the DNA on his lip were all addressed by the trial judge. On the former he said the cabbie's clothing suggested that he was going to have sex with the complainant. The DNA on the cabbie's lip (but no where else) was explained in the same general way. But even assuming that the cabbie's intent was to have sex with the passenger, that alone establishes nothing about consent.

The most logical conclusion from all the circumstantial evidence is that the cabbie and passenger were going to have sex. The judge states this explicitly. However there was zero evidence, circumstantial or otherwise, to show at what point the passenger became incapable of giving consent.

For the purpose of consent, trying to establish capacity from a text message is near impossible. I've had texts from people I knew to be sober but the message was near gibberish.

Why would we possibly think that we could actually influence governments on matters that they obviously don't care about. In many respects people are suffering from lecture fatigue. Comment: Bill: Indeed, there are statewide standards.  Seems folks don't want someone putting a hog farm next to a housing development.....

"The Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development (DLCD) is the chief land-use planning and regulatory agency of the government of the U.S. state of Oregon. The DLCD administers the statewide land use planning program. A seven-member volunteer citizen board known as the Land Conservation and Development Commission (LCDC) guides DLCD.

Oregon’s statewide land use planning program – originated in 1973 under Senate Bill 100 – provides protection of farm and forest lands, conservation of natural resources, orderly and efficient development, coordination among local governments, and citizen involvement. One of the primary objectives of the program is to create a predictable and sustainable development process by allocating land for industrial, commercial and housing needs within urban growth boundaries."

Regards, Gary Crum

Comment: Ron, check out PERS by the Numbers (available online), a comprehensive account of the PERS system and its history. The COLA was changed for all service time after Oct 1, 2013. Benefits have been reduced 22 different times since 1995. Just as with overall funding (PERS has over the years been overfunded as well as underfunded) and expected rate of returns, the system rules are a moving target. As reforms play out and conditions change, adjustments are needed. The Courts here have insisted only that changes not be retroactive in a way that would violate contracts. People move their families here to accept job offers that include specific salary and benefits promises. Historically, in some sectors, the salaries were very low and the benefits compensated. To work a lifetime at low salary and then have one's promised retirement benefits eliminated would be unjust. Contracts must be kept, so, by law, PERS payments will be made. Measure 97 is for Oregon's schools, seniors, and health care.

Comment: There is a tipping point coming if it isn't already here where we are going to have to make some tough choices about how much service we need and the role of public sector workers in it. 
We're close to reaching a saturation point on taxes and governments continue to spend more than they can afford. They need money and are taking it out of our pockets at an unsustainable rate. At this pace there will come a time in the not so distant future that we will have far fewer public servants which means major job losses and a huge recession. It's inevitable. I am not sure what the answer is but it seems like a conflict of interest to have government officials negotiating contracts of their own who are a major voting block. Comment: The design of these simple boxes with baffle on top haven’t changed much in 45 years or so, since USFS Campgrounds had them for fee stations near entrances.

Part of the design flaw has always been a lack of intricate mechanism, of weights, springs, a few more flaps that work only One-Way. Jr High or younger kids were known to have been using coat hanger wire, cable fishing leader, and actually fishing for envelopes in the early 1970s.

No actual hooks were used. A lot of ‘hand’ and a bend in hanger wire was the earlier method. Appears there are a few mild angles, into the box. Nothing too hard. 

One enterprising young man waited until his dad, a USFS boss, went on vacation; he asked to stay home to watch their house. With the extra sets of keys, he had a green car, special fuel pump, & keys to those lock boxes. And beer free money for a few months; plus the use of a car or sometimes a truck.

The son went to college, is paid well, now is a head republican, in MT state. ;)

Comment: Ashton,

You have confused the issue further by interchanging terms.  In fact, even the Author (obviously, a pro-2nd Amendment enthusiast) made this mistake in the article).

The Author writes, "The federal "assault rifle" ban that targeted AR-15 type firearms, was implemented in 1994 and in effect for 10 years. It was not renewed in 2004, because there was no realistic difference in "assault" rifle crime rates from before the ban was enacted through the 10-year period it was in affect.

In truth, the AR-15, and any other similarly-functioning weapon is NOT an "assault rifle".  And, the legislation enacted in 1994 (HR 4296 - Public Safety and Recreational Firearms Use Protection Act) was not targeted for "assault rifles".  HR 4296 was enacted to "prohibit the manufacture, transfer, or possession of a SEMIAUTOMATIC ASSAULT WEAPON (SAW) as defined or listed under this Act." (my emphasis in ALL CAPS).

Comment: Tax-deferred doesn't mean tax-free.  You still pay tax on it, just later.  Lowering the cap for the tax-deferred amount just means the tax is paid now rather than later.  That can mean you end up paying higher tax on it, or lower tax on it, or most likely, around the same tax on it.  You can't just look at what the tax will be this year and ignore that you won't be paying that tax 30 years later.

And few people come close to saving the full $18,000/yr tax-deferral allowed.  Those that do are pretty likely to have high income (the people the left usually say should be paying more taxes).  I'd think they'd be happy about that.  

Also, the assumption that you'll be taking less in disbursements than you make now is not necessarily correct.  It's like the assumption that you'll downsize to a smaller house when you retire.  But in many cases, just the opposite happens.  Especially for the people that can afford to save $18,000/yr.  Do that for 30 years in a decent investment (cont.)...

Comment: I hate to spend a lot of money for a place to sleep when I don't spend much time there.  I have used Air BnB in Seattle, New Orleans, Paris, New York and Reykjavik and have been pleased every time.  I got great information from the owners and in only one case did I not meet the owner, which I had been looking forward to after reading about her and corresponding back and forth with her several times.  In each case it was someone local who I stayed with, which is a great benefit in foreign countries especially.  I go for the inexpensive places but you can get whole houses or apartments with Air BnB.  If I don't find an Air BnB place that fits my needs, then I look for a hostel, not a hotel.  

When  I need to be at SeaTac for an early flight on Sundays, I stay in a cheap hotel/motel with van service to the airport since the Light Link Rail does not go early enough on Sunday mornings.

Interesting hosts are what I look for.  I cannot find that in a hotel.

Comment: Does that Florida example include the contribution from the other taxing authorities in Florida?  Other states commonly have echelons of taxing authority (e.g. City and County) that don't exist in many places in Alaska; therefore, the state is responsible for services that otherwise would be funded locally. Also, until recently, state bond reimbursement compensated the local governments who do impose local taxes.   Oil tax revenues have created an Alaska that is still locked into the paradigm that the state will be the primary source of public funding.

Comment: I'm amazed that Republicans still claim to have "won" the election. Where else on the planet does a democracy give the "win" to the political party that has fewer votes (over 2 million, at last count)?  Only in the USA can a loser (in the popular vote) claim victory.  Hollow victory, indeed.  

That said, I do agree that the "winners" need to shift from "whining" to ruling.  They need to deliver, and deliver fast.  But what can Republicans offer to the "losers" (the majority of voters)?   They cannot claim to have a "mandate" from the majority of voters.  Delivering (whatever) to benefit only their own constituencies will not win favor with the majority of voters who did NOT vote for Republicans.  And if the only "change" Republicans provide is undoing legislation from a previous administration, is that really progress?

Republicans need to remember that they LOST this election by over 2 million votes.  The will of the people has NOT been served by this election.  Deliver? Indeed!!

Again, it's a dream of mine to own one, or a few. I grew up afraid of horses and had never really been around one. Last Fall, at age 46, I went on the hunting trip of a lifetime with some guys from ND who brought 7 horses and a mule. 5 days on horseback in the Flattop Wilderness changed my life and I'd love nothing more than to be a "horse guy". Point is, I feel for those wild horses. I'd love for them to run wild and, well. . .  be horses. Unfortunately, that's not their reality.  Everything living dies. I'd rather they die quickly and humanely than starve if they have to die.

Comment: The electors referenced are indeed Democratic electors, and they are supposed to vote for Hilary given she carried WA state. Supposed to but not required. Interestingly, if there were enough electors from the states Trump won who refuse to vote for him, and cast their vote for another Republican, the Democratic electors could join in to add their votes for that person, and possibly create a surprise outcome. 

Note that Trump isn't elected until those forecasted electoral votes actually are cast for him on December 19. None of the electors has to vote for him. Being party faithful, they won't likely cross party boundaries, but they could, for instance, cast their votes for Pence and make him President instead. Or pick another person.

Per the Constitution, only the Electoral college can determine the President and Vice President.
